Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story:
The clock on the salon wall ticked closer to six, and my hands trembled as I tried to calm the furious client in my chair. She glared at her reflection, her voice rising with every complaint about the cut I’d just finished. I apologized, offered to fix it, but she wouldn’t be soothed. My coworkers glanced over, anxious to close up and go home. I felt their impatience, but I couldn’t rush her out—not if I wanted to uphold my reputation as a caring hairdresser.

Yet, in the back of my mind, the church bells tolled in my memory. Tonight was the most important religious holiday of the year, and as the community’s priest, I was expected to lead the prayers and offer comfort to the largest gathering we’d have all year. People would already be arriving, waiting for me to open the service. My phone buzzed with messages from parishioners, asking if I was on my way.

I stood between the mirror and the door, heart pounding, torn between the angry client demanding my attention and the congregation waiting for my guidance.
